qas.question: What did Chancellor Willy Brandt propose in his  28 October 1969 address?

answers.text: Article 29 of the Basic Law as a binding order

qas.question: Where did Chancellor Willy Brandt make his  28 October 1969 address?
An expert commission was established under which chairman?
When did the expert commission deliver its report?
Which state would the district of Germersheim be a part of?
Which chancellor proposed that article 29 should no longer be a binding order?
Who established an expert commission to discuss article 29?
When was an expert commission established?
What was the proposal for a single new state in the South?
What area was suggested should be separated from Hesse?

context: In his investiture address, given on 28 October 1969 in <a1_0>Bonn<a1_0/>, <b5_0>Chancellor Willy Brandt<b5_0/> proposed that the government would consider <a0_0>Article 29 of the Basic Law as a binding order<a0_0/>. An expert commission was established, named after its chairman, the former Secretary of State <b6_0>Professor <a2_0>Werner Ernst<b6_0/><a2_0/>. After two years of work, the experts delivered their report in <b7_0>1973<b7_0/>. It provided an alternative proposal for both northern Germany and central and southwestern Germany. In the north, either a single new state <b8_0>consisting of Schleswig-Holstein, Hamburg<b8_0/>, Bremen and Lower Saxony should be created (solution A) or two new states, one in the northeast consisting of Schleswig-Holstein, Hamburg and the northern part of Lower Saxony (from Cuxhaven to Lüchow-Dannenberg) and one in the northwest consisting of Bremen and the rest of Lower Saxony (solution B). In the Center and South West either <b9_0>Rhineland-Palatinate<b9_0/> (with the exception of the Germersheim district but including the Rhine-Neckar region) should be merged with Hesse and the Saarland (solution C), <a3_0>the district of Germersheim<a3_0/> would then become part of <a4_0>Baden-Württemberg<a4_0/>.
